chapter.htmlHeader: What else might it be?
chapter.htmlStringContent:
In adults or adolescents:

  • Scalp:
    • Psoriasis — presents with sharply demarcated scalp plaques. Plaques tend to be thicker with silvery white scales. Other signs (for example nail pitting and onycholysis) may help with the diagnosis.
      • For more information, see the CKS topic on Psoriasis.
    • Atopic or contact dermatitis — infected eczema may present with weeping and crusting, or with pustules.
      • For more information, see the CKS topics on Eczema – atopic and Dermatitis - contact.
    • Tinea capitis (fungal infection of the scalp) — presents with variable scaling. Inflammation, pruritus, and alopecia may be present.
      • For more information, see the CKS topics on Fungal skin infection – body and groin and Fungal skin infection – scalp.
  • Face:
    • Systemic lupus erythematosus — can present with a characteristic photosensitive maculopapular eruption with fine scaling in a 'butterfly' distribution on the cheeks.
    • Rosacea — can present with facial erythema in a cruciform pattern.
      • For more information, see the CKS topic on Rosacea.
    • Atopic or contact dermatitis — infected eczema may present with weeping and crusting, or with pustules.
      • For more information, see the CKS topics on Eczema – atopic and Dermatitis - contact.
  • Body:
    • Atopic eczema — can present with dryness and itching of the skin; flexural rash is common.
      • For more information, see the CKS topic on Eczema – atopic.
    • Pityriasis rosea — unlike seborrhoeic dermatitis, there is often a herald patch and lesions are less widely distributed.
      • For more information, see the CKS topic on Pityriasis rosea.
    • Pityriasis versicolor — flatter, extensive, less symmetrical than lesions of petaloid seborrhoeic dermatitis. Often noticed after a holiday when the person has been exposed to the sun.
      • For more information, see the CKS topic on Pityriasis versicolor.
    • Lichen simplex of the nape of the neck — thickened plaques can look like seborrhoeic dermatitis, but are intensely irritating.
    • Psoriasis — typically well-defined 'salmon pink' lesions with variable scaling which is often a characteristic silvery-white colour.
      • For more information, see the CKS topic on Psoriasis.
    • Candidiasis — may resemble seborrhoeic dermatitis of the groin.
      • For more information, see the CKS topic on Candida - skin.
    • Darier’s disease (a rare inherited skin condition) may affect sebaceous areas.
    • Hailey–Hailey disease (familial benign chronic pemphigus) may affect large flexures.
  • Some drugs and nutritional deficiencies may induce a seborrhoeic dermatitis-like rash:
    • Drugs include gold, haloperidol, lithium, chlorpromazine, cimetidine, interferon-alpha, methyldopa, and psoralens.
    • Nutritional deficiencies include pyridoxine, zinc, niacin and riboflavin.

In infants:

  • Atopic eczema — generally itchy, and may ooze or weep.
    • For more information, see the CKS topic on Eczema – atopic.
  • Scabies — can resemble widespread seborrhoeic dermatitis.
    • For more information, see the CKS topic on Scabies.
  • Psoriasis — can have a similar appearance to seborrhoeic dermatitis in infants.
    • For more information, see the CKS topic on Psoriasis.
  • Irritant contact dermatitis — can occur in the nappy area.
    • For more information, see the CKS topic on Dermatitis - contact.
  • Zinc deficiency.
  • Histiocytosis — rare; can affect the scalp, trunk, and nappy area.
  • Leiners disease — complement deficiency presenting with severe and widespread seborrhoeic dermatitis, recurrent infections, diarrhoea and failure to thrive.

[Gary, 2013; Ooi, 2014; Borda, 2015; Wakelin, 2016; BMJ Best Practice, 2018]
